metadata.title: Supervisors in the History of Science | by Manuel Cherep | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Supervisors in the History of Science
metadata.description: This is a data analysis of supervisor-student relations throughout the history of science. I attempt to discover using data science who are the most important supervisors in history. Before you go…

all_paragraphs: This is a data analysis of supervisor-student relations throughout the history of science. I attempt to discover using data science who are the most important supervisors in history.
Before you go on, let me suggest you to write down a prediction of great scientists that you expect to find in this analysis. I bet most of you will be partly surprised with the results.

Every project in data science consists of a problem to solve over some data. In this case our data set is fairly simple, so far it only contains relations between supervisors and students. For instance, we have a relation between Alfred Kleiner (supervisor) and Albert Einstein (student). In total, the data set has 7,070 unique people, with 6,517 students, 2,862 supervisors and 8,070 relations. Of course, many people are simultaneously supervisor and student.

All the data has been gathered from Wikipedia using simple scraping techniques. The data set contains all the people reachable from a pool of important people in science. The details are out of the scope of this post, and can be found on the github repository.

I want to stress the fact that the data set has no personal information whatsoever about the individuals. These harmless relations will reveal very interesting information about the history of science. Stay tuned!

I will explain briefly a few concepts that we need to go on. If you don’t have any mathematical background — baby don’t leave me — I promise it will be simple. If you do have some previous background on the (ultra) basics of graph theory, I recommend you to skip this section. I will review the concepts that will be used later on.

Graph theory is a field of mathematics that studies graphs (duh!). Graphs are clearly the structure that we are looking for in this case because graphs model relations. A graph is made of a set of nodes (people) connected by edges (supervisor-student relation).

As you might already be wondering, edges can connect nodes only in one direction (directed graphs) or in both directions (undirected graphs). For instance, supervising a student is represented by a unidirectional edge from the supervisor to the student. However, if we consider the supervisor-student relation to be connecting people that just know each other (e.g. social networks), then the edge connects the supervisor to the student and vice versa.

Why is this important at all? Well, a path between two nodes will be crucial for our analysis, and these two different structures allow completely different paths. Which one makes more sense for you to analyse our data?
First, we model the relations as an undirected graph. This decision has an important impact on the analysis, as it considers supervisors and students equally important.

A connected component in a graph is a subgraph where all the nodes are reachable from at least another node. Our graph has 84 connected components, but the largest component accounts for 95.81% of all the nodes. This is already quite impressive, since we gathered data from a pool of people from different fields (e.g. chemistry, computer science). This shows how all these fields have a common ancestor, which will prove to be the field of mathematics.

The degree of a node 𝑣 in an undirected graph is the number of edges that connect 𝑣 with other nodes (i.e. the number of people connected to a particular person). This is the ranking of the first ten in terms of their degree:

This list is already interesting and probably you recognize some of them. Keep them in mind, as they will appear later. Besides the first ten, this is the degree distribution for all the nodes in the graph
As we can observe, most people are only connected to their supervisor and have a degree of one, while a few people have many connections. This is known as a power law distribution in statistics.

Betweenness centrality measures the centrality of a node 𝑣, as the proportion of shortest paths from all pairs of nodes that pass through 𝑣. In this case, we can use this measure of centrality to extract insights about the importance of people in the graph. If a node finds itself in the shortest path connecting other nodes then it is essential for that connection. The ranking:

All of them, except Hermann Helmholtz and John von Neumann, were born in the 19th century and died in the 20th century. Helmholtz almost made it alive to the 20th century, and von Neumann was born at the very beginning. They are so crucial in the graph (and in the history of science) because they are part of the generation that connects the greatest mathematicians from the 18th century with the greatest scientists of the 20th and 21st centuries.

The award goes to David Hilbert!. Born in Germany, Hilbert was one of the most influential and universal mathematicians in history. Among Hilbert’s students we can find mathematicians Hermann Weyl and Haskell Curry.

We can also see Nobel laureate Max Born, German physicist and mathematician vital in the development of quantum mechanics. Among Born’s students we find the Nobel laureates Maria Goeppert-Mayer, Enrico Fermi and Max Delbrück. Another of his students was Robert Oppenheimer, head of the Los Alamos Laboratory during the Manhattan Project, where the first atomic bomb was developed.

German physicist Arnold Sommerfeld, pioneer in the field of quantum physics, is among the top two with the most students winners of a Nobel prize. We have already seen that Sommerfeld has the largest number of connections in our graph. Sommerfeld’s students include the Nobel laureates Werner Heisenberg, Wolfgang Pauli, Hans Bethe, Peter Debye, Linus Pauling, Isidor Isaac Rabi and Max von Laue. In fact, Albert Einstein once told Sommerfeld that he admired how he pounded out of the soil such a large number of young talents. Sommerfeld is arguably the best supervisor in the history of science, famous for meeting with his students in his home or in cafes. Sommerfeld also owned a ski cabin where students were invited for discussions about physics. Something interesting is the fact that Sommerfeld never won a Nobel prize himself, even though he was nominated a record of 84 times.

On the other side, we also have British physicist and Nobel prize laureate J. J. Thomson, the only one who can compete with Sommerfeld in terms of students with a Nobel prize. Thomson, credited with the discovery of the electron, had among his students Nobel laureates Charles Glover Barkla, Niels Bohr, Max Born, William Henry Bragg, Owen Willans Richardson, Charles Thomson Rees Wilson, Francis William Aston and Ernest Rutherford. In fact, Thomson’s son (George Paget Thomson) won the 1937 Nobel Prize in physics, a feat only achieved as well by the Bragg’s, Bohr’s and Siegbahn’s.

Russian mathematician Solomon Lefschetz, with fundamental work on algebraic topology and geometry, supervised John McCarthy, one of the founders of artificial intelligence, and John Tukey, an important figure in statistics.

Hermann von Helmholtz was a German physicist who made significant contributions in several fields such as human vision, electrodynamics and thermodynamics. Among his students we can find the Nobel laureates Albert Michelson, Wilhelm Wien, Max Planck and Gabriel Lippmann.

Finally, on the list we can also find John von Neumann, Hungarian mathematician, physicist and computer scientist. Von Neumann is arguably one of the most intelligent people who have ever walked the Earth. He’s one of my favourite scientists of all time, so I can’t dare to describe his work briefly. I can only say, that if you don’t know him well, it is worth reading about him. Just for fun, open his Wikipedia page and find the section ‘Known for’ below his picture on the right.

Eigenvector centrality is a different way of measuring centrality. In this case the importance of a node increases when it is related to another important node. This concept is similar to the one used by Google in its PageRank algorithm. Once again, the ranking:
If you happened to read the section on betweenness centrality, you are already familiar with most of the people on the list.

It is fascinating that with this measure of centrality we can find the importance of Arnold Sommerfeld without knowing anything about his students, just based on the nature of his descendants. Most of the people on the list are in fact directly related to Arnold Sommerfeld.

There are three scientists that we did not see in the previous measure of centrality. Rudolph Peierls, supervised by Werner Heisenberg; Ferdinand von Lindemann, supervisor of Arnold Sommerfeld and David Hilbert among others; and Gregor Wentzel, supervised by Arnold Sommerfeld.
It is surprising to see that J. J. Thomson, 13th on the list, is not among the top ten, since he supervised so many Nobel prize laureates.

A bridge is an edge whose deletion disconnects the graph. The number of bridge edges of a node gives us a good measure of how important the node is connecting different parts of the graph, which might be related to different fields. The ranking:
Once again, there are a lot of familiar faces, which is also a good indication that we are doing things right.

Franz Boas is very interesting. He was a German anthropologist who supervised many students, becoming the backbone for that field. It might be surprising that an anthropologist is in the data set, however, we can trace Franz Boas back to Abraham Gotthelf Kästner, a common ancestor for Carl Gustav Jacob Jacobi.

American economist and Nobel laureate Robert Solow is also an important node for the field of economics, with students such as the Nobel laureates George Akerlof, Joseph Stiglitz, Peter Diamond and William Nordhaus.
Others like Alonzo Church, Richard Karp or Marvin Minsky are crucial connections between the fields of mathematics and computer science, where the latest two have won the Turing Award.

We also find some other great mathematicians such as Salomon Bochner, Felix Klein, Garrett Birkhoff, John Tate and Elias Stein. Felix Klein is widely known for contributions in several different fields of mathematics. As an spoiler of what we will see at the end of this post, Felix Klein is part of a remarkable path of supervisor-students that starts with Lagrange and ends with John von Neumann.
John Archibald Wheeler, an American physicist responsible for reviving interest in general relativity, was supervisor of Nobel laureates Richard Feynman and Kip Thorne.

At the very end of the list we come across Noam Chomsky, a pivotal connection between the fields of mathematics and linguistics. Chomsky is the only one together with Thorne that we have mentioned and are still alive today.

Now, we change the model to an undirected graph, which attributes more importance to the supervisor than the student. Why are we doing this? Well, with this change we expect to find the founders of mathematics more relevant than the rest, simply because they are at the top of the genealogy tree.

We are going to carry out the same analysis as we did with the undirected graph, so for a definition of this measure please refer to the previous section. The main difference with the previous analysis is that in this case paths are only valid in the direction from the supervisor to the student. The ranking (removing outliers):

What a wonderful list, as satisfying as it gets. Indeed, we have found some of the founders of mathematics as we know it today. In this case, we have a mix of mathematicians born in the 18th and the 19th centuries.

These are some of the greatest mathematicians, and if you have any mathematical education, I’m sure you know most of their names. There are also many great early mathematicians missing and worth mentioning: Bernhard Riemann, Henri Poincaré, Pierre de Fermat, Gottfried Leibniz, Évariste Galois, Karl Weierstrass, Niels Abel, Carl Jacobi, Augustin-Louis Cauchy, Joseph Fourier and Pierre-Simon Laplace, to name a few.
In graph theory, a path is a sequence of edges which connect a sequence of nodes. As promised in the sub-section ‘Bridges’, there are some remarkable paths in this graph worth visualizing.

This is hopefully the first analysis of many over this data set. However, for future analysis I will try to gather personal information about people. We have seen the importance of mathematicians specially from Germany and France, and as we grow the graph and the years go by, we might be able to find a swift change towards American scientists.

I started this project because I’ve been looking for supervisors myself, and I wanted to learn more about the history of the supervision. I am certain, as we have seen today, of the importance of finding a suitable supervisor. In fact, if you are in a similar position to mine, I can recommend reading ‘A PhD Is Not Enough!’.
One last thought that I want to share, is the importance of mathematics. Everything is mathematics, and as it becomes more specific, receives more specific names.
If you are particularly interested in a scientist that I haven’t mentioned or you want to comment anything with me, let me know in the comments.

If you are interested in learning more about graph theory to apply it in a similar way, I really recommend Network Science by Albert-László Barabási. It’s great and available for free online in many languages.
Here is my github repository for the project in case the code is useful for you. Please, give it a star if you’ve found this project interesting, I would very much appreciate it.
Fulbright Scholar at MIT Media Lab
